title: Jane Fonda arrested again at climate change protest; 'Good Place' star Ted Danson also arrested
text:
CLOSE The Green New Deal has its share of supporters and critics, but the often-misunderstood plan is just the start of environmental politics. We explain. Just the FAQs, USA TODAY

Jane Fonda was arrested for the third time amid a climate change protest Friday. "The Good Place" star Ted Danson was also arrested at the Washington, D.C. protest.

In an email to USA TODAY Friday, Ira Arlook of Fire Drill Fridays confirmed Fonda and Danson's arrests. Photos and videos of the arrests have also been shared on social media.

The actress, 81, organized Fire Drill Fridays, an initiative which aims to have politicians address climate change.

USA TODAY has reached out to the Danson's rep for comment.

In a letter shared to Fire Drill Friday's website, Fonda said she's "moved to Washington, D.C. to be closer to the epicenter of the fight for our climate."

She added: "Every Friday through January, I will be leading weekly demonstrations on Capitol Hill to demand that action by our political leaders be taken to address the climate emergency we are in. We can't afford to wait."

CLOSE Inspired by the climate activism of Swedish teen Greta Thunberg, Jane Fonda says she's returned to civil disobedience in support of a Green New Deal. (Oct. 18) AP, AP

In addition to her recent arrests, Fonda was previously arrested for "drug smuggling" at the Cleveland Hopkins International Airport in 1970, according to her website.

"I was handcuffed and put in the Cleveland Jail, which is when the mug shot was taken," she writes. "I was released on bond and months later, after every pill had been tested in a lab (with taxpayers money!) The charges were dismissed and there were a few paragraphs hidden in the back of papers that they were vitamins, not drugs."

Contributing: Erin Jensen
